abstract.t: The Network Management Research Group (NMRG) started an activity to collect traces of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) from operational networks. To analyze these traces, it is necessary to split potentially large traces into more manageable pieces that also make it easier to deal with large data sets and simplify the analysis of the data.

This document provides some common definitions that have been found useful for implementing tools to support trace analysis. This document mainly serves as a reference for the the definitions underlying these tools and it is not meant to explain all the motivation and resoning behind the definitions. Some of this background information can be found in other research papers.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Network Management Research Group (NMRG) started an activity to collect traces of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) from operational networks. To analyze these traces, it is necessary to split potentially large traces into more manageable pieces that also make it easier to deal with large data sets and simplify the analysis of the data.

This document provides some common definitions that have been found useful for implementing tools to support trace analysis. This document mainly serves as a reference for the the definitions underlying these tools and it is not meant to explain all the motivation and resoning behind the definitions. Some of this background information can be found in other research papers.
More information and the motivation for SNMP trace collection and analysis can be found in RFC XXXX .

section.title: Message Flows
section.t: Notation: Let M be a message of an SNMP trace T. We denote the properties of M as follows:
section.artwork: M.type = operation type of message M (get, getnext, ...) M.class = class of message M (according RFC 3411) M.tsrc = transport layer source endpoint of message M M.tdst = transport layer destination endpoint of message M M.nsrc = network layer source endpoint of message M M.ndst = network layer destination endpoint of message M M.reqid = request identifier of message M M.time = capture timestamp of message M
section.t: Definition (command messages): The set of command messages of an SNMP trace T consists of all messages M in T satisfying the following conditions:

list.t: M is a Read class [RFC3411] message or
M is a Write class [RFC3411] messages or

M is a Response class [RFC3411] messages and there exists a Read class or Write class message R such that the following holds:
M.reqid = R.reqid M.tdst = R.tsrc M.nsrc = R.ndst (M.time - R.time) < t

section.t: The parameter t defines a maximum timeout for response messages.
Definition (notification messages): The set of notification messages of an SNMP trace T consists of all messages M in T satisfying the following conditions:

list.t: M is a Notfication class [RFC3411] message or

M is a Response class [RFC3411] message and there exists a Notification class [RFC3411] message R such that the following holds:
M.reqid = R.reqid M.tdst = R.tsrc M.nsrc = R.ndst (M.time - R.time) < t

section.t: The parameter t defines a maximum timeout for response messages.
Definition (flow): A flow F is the set of messages of an SNMP trace T with the following properties:

list.t: All messages belong to a single source and destination network address pair.
All messages are either command group messages, notification group messages, or internal group messages.
All Response class messages originate from a single network address.
All non-Response class messages originate from a single network address.

section.t: Subsequently, we call flows containing command messages command flows. Similarily, we call flows containing notification messages notification flows.
Notation: Let F be a flow as defined above. We denote the properties of F as follows:
section.artwork: F.type = type of the flow F (command / notification / internal flow) F.nsrc = network layer source endpoint of F F.ndst = network layer destination endpoint of F F.start = time stamp of the first message in F F.end = time stamp of the last message in F
section.t: This definition of a flow is consistent with the definition of a flow in the paper .

section.title: FLow Slices
section.t: Definition (linked): A Response/GetNext or Response/GetBulk message pair is linked if the following holds:

list.t: The request message (GetNext or GetBulk) must contain at least one OID which has been contained in the (repeater) varbind list of the last response message of a previous request message.

section.t: Definition (slice): A slice S is a subset of messages in a flow F for which the following properties hold:

list.t: All messages are exchanged between two transport endpoints (a single transport address pair).
All request messages must be of the same type.
All Get, Set, Trap, Inform messages must contain the same set of OIDs.
All Response messages must follow a previous request message that is part of the same slice.
All GetNext or GetBulk message must either contain the same set of OIDs or they must be linked to the last response of the previous request.
For a request message Q following the last response message R to the previous request, the condition (Q.time - R.time) < e is true.

section.t: Notation: A slice S has several properties. We introduce the following notation:
section.artwork: S.type = type of non-response messages in S S.start = time stamp of the first message in S S.end = time stamp of the last message in S S.prefix = set of prefixes of messages in S /* [TODO] */

Def: A session type is a type mark identifying sessions
(1) All messages have been exchanged between the same transport endpoints. (really transport?) (2) All READ, WRITE, NOTIFY messages originate from the same transport endpoint. (really transport???) (3) All non-response messages are of the same type
Def: A session set is a set of sessions that have the following properties:
(1) All READ, WRITE, NOTIFY messages originate from the same transport endpoint. (really transport???) (2) (3) All messages occurred within a specific time frame of each other.

section.title: Walks
section.t: Definition (walk): A walk W is a slice S with the following properties:

list.t: The type of the slice S is either get-next-request or get-bulk-request.
